utterances: I would just go to say that all of what Joe just said about the comparison between using military force in Somalia and so maybe we can do it here, it also means that we will think that - it assumes that we think that genocide is at least as important to get rid of as terrorism because of facts on the ground.

Our history so far, in terms of Africa, if Rwanda is any example -and we hope it's a bad example - is that we really don't care that much.

Let's stay with another story out of Africa.

It seems that government officials and Guinea-Bissau are anxious to connect with their distant daughter, Whoopi Goldberg.
Now you remember a number of celebrities took DNA tests in connection with the PBS special last year.
It turns out that the Academy Award-wining actress' ancestors very likely come for that area.
Now Guinea-Bissau is one of the poorest countries on the continent.
Its leaders were hoping that the relationship with Whoopi Goldberg might do something to draw attention…
Hoppy Goldberg.
Hoppy Goldberg.
Her letter said her Excellency, Hoppy Goldberg.
They wrote her a letter asking to be delivered through the embassy asking her to come to visit.
It's unfortunate Whoopi Goldberg is afraid to fly.
So it seems unlikely that she'll be visiting any time soon.
But, you know, what do you think of that strategy, Joe?
Well, I think it really points to how desperate, unfortunately, some African countries are for international attention.

I think that if you have to kind of grab on to an American entertainer in order to draw attention to your small West African country it shows just how far off the radar screen you are for most Americans.
And so I frankly see it as a desperate act to get attention.
Have any of you done this, gotten your DNA tested?
No.
Not yet, no.
No.

And Troy Duster at NYU points out that there are all kinds of scientific questions about whether these all makes any sense, and that it only really traces one spike in your ancestry back to some paternal ancestry like generations ago on spike, nothing on the maternal side.
And that it…
Oh Mary.
…could have been some European trade - slave trader who was there.
But in any case, leaving all that side.
All the women say this.
Leaving that aside, which is too complicated.

I just think that if people are going to have their DNA tested, and if they are entertainers and big shots and they have money and they're proud that they're from this particular place in Africa, maybe they should help the poor people over there rather than just saying isn't it great, I'm from whatever tribe it is.
And white entertainers when they - like Madonna adopting that child and so on, little countries try to take advantage of that in some way to get publicity because they're all poor.
So this is not unusual.
And Whoopi just (unintelligible) over here by boat - even though she can't fly, she could get on a boat and go over there if she really wanted to.
She could also send a check too, right?
She has - this is an interesting question because I wonder if some people listen to this and if this sort of plays into some subliminal fears.

I mean, you can imagine people saying, you know what, I already have relatives in my pocket over here and don't I need anymore relatives in my pocket that I don't even - I mean isn't this kind of your worst case scenario if you won the lottery, that, you know, relatives you don't even know would be asking for this.
Now, you've got a whole country you got to deal with.
You got a whole country.
Oh God.
At the same time, it's clear that in the black communities we really do need to put an emphasis on early childhood preparation, elementary school preparation, junior high preparation.
So by the time our children get to high school, they will be much better prepared to take the courses that they need in order to get into college.

But this is not the only African country that is starting to - and Caribbean country trying to reach out to the diaspora, you know, that this is the 50th anniversary of Ghanaian independence is coming up.
Ghana has the Joseph Project, where they're trying to interest African-Americans or Africans of the diaspora to come home, as they say.
The Jamaican prime minister, Portia Simpson-Miller, is reaching out to Jamaican ex-patriots.
So part of me wonders whether - do you think this is a fruitful strategy?
Well, it's certainly a common strategy.
I mean, certainly if you look at countries like Ireland, if you look at Israel, for example, there are major efforts to tie people in this country to their homeland.
And so there are certainly nothing wrong and there certainly it is perfectly okay for African countries to do the same thing.

I think the difference between countries like Israel and Ireland, for example, is that they do it much more systematically and that the people in this country who are of Irish descent or who will have links to Israel also are much better organized to help their homelands than African-Americans by and large are.
But Nat hasn't had a chance to -
Michel, no, I've got to say this.

That there's a whole field of African diasporic studies in universities and colleges, and research going on and courses that tie together the Caribbean, Africa and the United States and the African-American experience, so that in the sense - and people go to Africa for conferences and all that and the Caribbean.
So it does fit in systematically with that notion.
But what I was going to say is - and thank you for bring that in Dr. Berry.
Always - it helps to have your corrective help there.
But it used to be that really mainly elites, intellectuals, journalists, entertainers were the ones who forge these ties.
And Nat Irvin, what I was wondering about, do you think this is - we are at a point at which African-Americans feel secure enough on the whole to start forging these ties in the way that you have.
You know, regular folks, I think

Sure.

In fact, Michel…
…where you just more of a grassroots phenomenon.

Well, in fact, the way that I test this assumption is I interview cab drivers all the time when I'm in D.C.
and actually just regular folks to find out what the relationships are with the Caribbean, with the continent.
And you would be surprised to find a number of people who are planning on retiring either in the Caribbean or on the continent; Ghana seems to be one of the places.
There's a lot of activity between African-Americans in Rwanda and Botswana.
There's a lot of - what I think people are just under the radar.
And one of the, you know, when you look at what the Joseph Project is about, it says the 21st century will be the African century.
It may be a stretch.
But look, the aspiration is there.

And if the - and there's something going on within the consciousness, I think both of the continent and black people in America to where I'm just starting to notice more often you'll see people with dual citizenships and thinking about doing projects there, business projects.
It's not at all something just for the elites; it's a lot more common than people may care to realize.

Thanks.

I wanted to bring one more topic.
And I was very interested in this because all of you teach or you have taught at universities.
And I saw this story - it said the College Board, which administers the SAT and AP test for high school students, released a 10-year report this weekend.
It turns out that some kids are taking too many AP courses.
Now these courses, of course, as you know, register, I mean - sorry, measure achievement in college level, where clearly I didn't take any.
An executive director of the AP programs said some kids are overdoing it.
Now do you - now all of you teach or have taught at university level.
Does this square with your sense of the way it is?
That kids are just putting too much pressure on themselves, Dr. Berry.
Well, they're so worried about getting into a, quote, ""good college,"" and their parents are so worried about it that this all feeds into that over-anxiety and over-activity.
So they miss out on a lot of what should be high school life.
And what interested me is one student said well, even after doing all this, when I go to college, it will be easier.
No, it will be harder because there will be even more competition.
So they need to relax and take a little time to think and, sure, have achievement.
But they can get into a good college with good grades and having done something besides taking AP courses.
Maybe help out in the community a little bit or do something of that kind.
So I think that there's an overemphasis on this kind of activity.
I disagree with Mary.
I think that - although I understand Mary's point - I just think that when we talk about the opportunities and challenges that are facing minority communities, I think competition is the key.
The key - for me it's a simple thing as this.
In India, there are newspapers daily which children are solving algebraic equations.
Competing, everyday there's a question, and kids are competing to solve the equation for the next day.

When we look at what the competition is for the future that comes from both Asia, from China, and from other parts of the world, it is imperative and especially to me for minority kids to be competitive.
I don't think we're nearly at our capacity when it comes to what we are capable of doing.
Balance is the key, but I don't think that - we're not suffering from a lack of balance.
Joe, final thought, quick final thought.
I think balance is the key, as Nat said.
And so I think that's where the bridge between Mary and Nat comes.
You can be competitive without being so competitive that you drive yourself into a nervous state, which apparently is happening with some of our children today.
Exactly.
